unnormalised: Healthcare in India can be a maze, right? Especially when dealing with all those ID numbers. You’ve got your Aadhaar, which seems to be linked to everything these days, and then there’s the UHID - that's the Unique Health Identification number. My friend Priya spent ages figuring it all out when her dad got admitted to Max Hospital Saket.
normalised: Healthcare in India can be a maze, right? Especially when dealing with all those I-D numbers. You’ve got your Aadhaar, which seems to be linked to everything these days, and then there’s the U-H-I-D - that's the Unique Health Identification number. My friend Priya spent ages figuring it all out when her dad got admitted to Max Hospital Saket.

unnormalised: The UHID, apparently, is supposed to be a national system, but each hospital still kinda has its own. So, Apollo Chennai gave her dad a different UHID compared to the one he already had from AIIMS Delhi. Total confusion! Plus, there's the Ayushman Bharat ID, for those covered under that scheme. It's all a bit much, honestly. Don’t even get me started on trying to understand which insurance card covers what.
normalised: The U-H-I-D, apparently, is supposed to be a national system, but each hospital still kinda has its own. So, Apollo Chennai gave her dad a different U-H-I-D compared to the one he already had from A-I-I-M-S Delhi. Total confusion! Plus, there's the Ayushman Bharat I-D, for those covered under that scheme. It's all a bit much, honestly. Don’t even get me started on trying to understand which insurance card covers what.

unnormalised: And then there's the insurance part. Every insurance company issues a different policy number. Like, my Star Health policy has one number (SH0987654), while my friend Rakesh's ICICI Lombard policy has another (ICICI-LH/2023/1234). Remembering these on top of everything else when someone’s unwell? Almost impossible! I always end up rummaging through old emails and documents.
normalised: And then there's the insurance part. Every insurance company issues a different policy number. Remembering these on top of everything else when someone’s unwell? Almost impossible! I always end up rummaging through old emails and documents.

unnormalised: The whole system needs to be streamlined, ya know? Imagine having one, universal health ID that works everywhere, links to your insurance, and stores all your medical records. It would save so much time and stress. Maybe something like a "Digital Health Card", connected with ABHA ID like 1234-5678-9012-3456. We can only hope, right?
